title: 109-E
statement: E. Lucky Intervaltime limit per test4 secondsmemory limit per test512 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutPetya loves lucky numbers. We all know that lucky numbers are the positive integers whose decimal representations contain only the lucky digits4and7. For example, numbers47,744,4are lucky and5,17,467are not.One day Petya came across an interval of numbers[a,a+l- 1]. LetF(x)be the number of lucky digits of numberx. Find the minimumb(a<b)such, thatF(a)=F(b),F(a+ 1)=F(b+ 1), ...,F(a+l- 1)=F(b+l- 1).InputThe single line contains two integersaandl(1 ≤a,l≤ 109) — the interval's first number and the interval's length correspondingly.OutputOn the single line print numberb— the answer to the problem.ExamplesInput7 4Output17Input4 7Output14NoteConsider that[a,b]denotes an interval of integers; this intervalincludesthe boundaries. That is,

processed.result:
Given an interval of numbers $[a, a+l-1]$, find the smallest number $b$ such that the number of lucky digits in each corresponding number within the intervals $[a, a+l-1]$ and $[b, b+l-1]$ is the same. 

Lucky digits are 4 and 7.

Given a starting number and a length, find the smallest number that, when combined with the starting number, has the same count of lucky digits (digits 4 and 7) in each corresponding position within the range.
